G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as it is a civil action in which the damages exceed $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Berkshire County pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to the claim occurred in Pittsfield, within Berkshire County, Massachusetts.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a property owner owes a duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on or adjacent to his property to prevent foreseeable harm from conditions under his control.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the invitee/licensee distinction and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by landowners to all lawful entrants. While this quoted passage is from a concurrence critiquing the treatment of trespassers, it confirms the majority’s shift away from status-based duties toward a unified standard of reasonable care for those lawfully on the premises. Massachusetts courts have read Mounsey as establishing that owners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors with respect to conditions under their control; the proposition accurately reflects that holding, though the concurrence also suggests the logic should extend further toward trespassers.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors… Thus it is awkward to leave the suggestion that the basic reasoning of the court’s opinion may stop short of so called trespassers.

*Cohen v. Davies*, 305 Mass. 152 (1940)..proposition: This duty extends to conditions that pose a risk to persons using an adjacent public sidewalk.
*Cohen v. Davies*, 305 Mass. 152 (1940)..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a landlord’s duty to a tenant/licensee injured by a small fence on an interior courtyard lawn and turns on whether the plaintiff was using a designated common passageway. It does not involve or discuss any duty relating to conditions creating risks to users of an adjacent public sidewalk, nor does it extend the landlord’s duty beyond the common areas intended for tenant use. The proposition about risks to persons on a public sidewalk is therefore not addressed or supported by this case.
*Cohen v. Davies*, 305 Mass. 152 (1940)..relevant_excerpt: “It is the rule, with some qualifications immaterial to this case, that a landlord is bound to keep the areas intended to be used in common by his tenants in reasonably safe condition for the use contemplated. He is not bound, however, to keep them safe for uses to which they were not meant to be put. … It does not appear that there would be any danger resulting from their position to one properly using the designated walks.”

*Whiting v. City of Boston*, 106 Mass. 8.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to maintain the tree on his property in a reasonably safe condition and to take timely action when the branch became visibly cracked and hazardous.
*Whiting v. City of Boston*, 106 Mass. 8.case_name: Whiting v. Mayor & Aldermen of Boston
*Whiting v. City of Boston*, 106 Mass. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with assessments for public street improvements, the validity of a statutory lien, delay in public works, and related municipal-law and procedural issues. It does not address premises liability, duties regarding trees on private property, or any obligation to maintain a tree or act when a branch becomes hazardous. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the stated duty-to-maintain-tree proposition.
*Whiting v. City of Boston*, 106 Mass. 8.relevant_excerpt: "We do not propose to consider whether such a claim of damages could be maintained against the city, or against the mayor and aldermen in any form. Even if a liability to such damages could be substantiated, in accordance with the principles laid down in Child v. Boston, 4 Allen, 41, we do not think it can be set up against an assessment required for paying the expenses of a public improvement, with which the mayor and aldermen are charged as public officers."

*Brown v. Kendall*, 6 Cush. 292 (Mass. 1.proposition: Defendant knew or reasonably should have known that the cracked branch posed an unreasonable risk of falling and injuring passersby, thereby breaching the duty of reasonable care.

*Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 378.proposition: Defendant’s failure to inspect or remove the dangerous branch constituted negligence and a breach of the duty owed to Plaintiff.
*Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 378.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence focused on premises liability classifications (trespasser, licensee, invitee) and the abolition of those distinctions. It does not discuss inspection duties, dangerous branches, or whether failure to inspect or remove a branch constituted negligence. Therefore, this excerpt does not provide authority for the specific negligence proposition stated.
*Soule v. Massachusetts Elec. Co.*, 378.relevant_excerpt: Concurring, I must, in contrast to the Chief Justice, express disappointment at the intimation in the next-to-last paragraph of the court’s opinion that the liability of an occupier for negligence might still be made to turn in this jurisdiction on the mere circumstance, without more, that the plaintiff had the common law status of a so called trespasser at the time of the occurrence in suit.

*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.raw_text: *Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515 (1st Cir. 1990).
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was not that of a reasonably prudent homeowner under the same or similar circumstances.
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns negligence by an airport authority and whether damages for harm to reputation are recoverable in an ordinary negligence case and sufficiently proven. It does not analyze the standard of care for a homeowner or discuss what a reasonably prudent homeowner would do under similar circumstances. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about a reasonably prudent homeowner’s conduct.
*Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: "In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury." (905 F.2d at 535). [Note: No discussion of a reasonably prudent homeowner appears in the opinion.]

*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries were directly and proximately caused by Defendant’s negligent omission and failure to remedy the dangerous condition.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that the defendant was not negligent and that his failure to modify or repair the elevator ceiling or to post warnings did not constitute a breach of duty. The court concludes there was no duty to protect against the obvious risk of putting a long board through the elevator ceiling and thus no actionable negligent omission that directly and proximately caused the injury. Therefore, the case does not support a proposition that plaintiff’s injuries were directly and proximately caused by defendant’s negligent failure to remedy a dangerous condition; it stands for the opposite result.
*Toubiana v. Priestly*, 402 Mass. 84 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, the jury was unwarranted in inferring that an ordinarily prudent person in the relevant circumstances would have provided a solid elevator ceiling or a printed warning concerning the danger of extending materials from the moving elevator into the elevator shaft. It follows that the defendant’s failure to adopt either of those measures did not constitute negligence.”

*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff sustained physical harm, medical expenses, lost income, and pain and suffering.
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion clearly establishes that the defendant was negligent and that Morgan suffered serious injuries, but it does not detail categories such as medical expenses, lost income, or pain and suffering, nor does it frame them as the legally recognized damages resulting from the negligence. The case is about comparative negligence and consortium/parental society issues, not about itemizing or recognizing specific elements of damages as a matter of law. Thus it only implicitly, not authoritatively, supports the claimed proposition.
*Morgan v. Lalumiere*, 22 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Morgan was seriously injured in the accident. She spent more than five weeks in the hospital, endured two operations, and remains severely disabled. She brought suit against Lalumiere and his father alleging that her injuries were caused by Lalumiere’s negligence. … The jury’s verdict was in the form of answers to special questions. They found that Morgan had suffered damages as a result of the accident in the amount of $160,000.”

*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition violated the applicable standard of care recognized in *Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739 (1995).
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The case does restate the general premises-liability rule that landowners must maintain their premises in a reasonably safe condition, but its actual holding is that the defendant racetrack *did not* owe a duty to alter or control the adjacent state highway or provide a pedestrian bridge/traffic signal. The opinion ultimately finds no breach of any such expanded duty and reverses the judgment against the defendant. Using Davis as authority that a defendant’s failure to maintain premises in a reasonably safe condition violated the standard of care mischaracterizes the case’s holding, which limits, rather than expands, the duty in these circumstances.
*Davis v. Westwood Group*, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. … In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land, nor was there any condition on its land that created an unreasonable risk to users of Route 1A.

*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is liable for all damages proximately caused by his negligent acts or omissions.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs.*, 386 Mass. 540.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses various limits on negligence liability (e.g., requirements for physical harm in emotional distress claims, wrongful life bar, prenatal injury, and identification of manufacturers), but it nowhere states the general rule that a defendant is liable for all damages proximately caused by his negligence. Proximate cause and the scope of damages are assumed rather than analyzed, and no broad Massachusetts damages principle of the kind asserted in the proposition is articulated or reaffirmed. Therefore this case does not serve as authority for that proposition.

G.L. c. 261, \u00a7 1 et seq..proposition: Costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 261, § 1 et seq.;
